text: food companies spend billions of dollars
each year to make their products
irresistible to consumers and it works
obesity rates are at shocking levels we
have a super-sized culture and Americans
are eating more and more but you
wouldn't know it from the serving sizes
listed on many packaged foods which
often seem to bear no relation to how
people really eat the federal government
sets the laws governing food labeling
and serving size but many people say the
current regulations are outdated and in
need of change nutrition labels are
supposed to help people make good
decisions about healthy eating just
about every package of food that you buy
in the grocery store has a nutrition
label on it it tells you the amount of
calories fat salt sugar and other
ingredients but serving size is the key
to everything it determines the amount
of calories and all the other nutrients
on the label but if you make the serving
size too small unless people study the
label carefully they may think they're
getting fewer calories less salt less
sugar than they really are the results
can be pretty bizarre let's start with
breakfast but not the big bowl of
frosted flakes that you're used to
having the federal government says that
a serving of breakfast cereals is 3/4 of
a cup now that's not very much and even
Kellogg's would seem to suggest that
most people want to eat more because
they make a go cup of frosted flakes
with twice that amount
Kellogg's also puts a lot of the
nutrition information right on the front
of the box that way parents can get a
look and see what their kids are getting
but they may look at this and see a
hundred and ten calories and think
that's not that much without realizing
it's a hundred and ten calories per
serving many kids are probably eating
two to three times that much every
morning now let's say you don't want
cereal you'd rather have a muffin well
here's a blueberry muffin and I look at
the package and it tells me that a
muffin has 220 calories but wait a
minute a serving size is half a muffin
that's 220 calories for half of one
these if I eat the whole thing
which I'm probably gonna do that means
that I've had 440 calories that's about
a quarter of all the calories that an
average person eats in a day a 2,000
calorie diet now on to lunch here I've
got my microwavable bowl of healthy
choice soup it says right on the front
of the label that it has a hundred and
thirty calories and 440 milligrams of
sodium it's even got the seal of the
Heart Association this is clearly made
to be heated up and eaten by one person
at a sitting
but wait a minute the label on the back
tells me there's about two servings in
here so all of these values that I've
read upfront have to be doubled I'm
actually getting double the calories and
about 800 milligrams of salt that's
about half of what the government says
many people should be getting in a day
now with my soup I want some chips here
we go but wait a minute it says a
serving is six chips oh it's just six
chips all that label studying has given
me an appetite for some good comfort
food how about a nice big plate of
spaghetti not so fast
the label says that a single serving of
spaghetti is one eighth of a package
that's two ounces so I measured out two
ounces and cooked it up it's not the
stingiest portion in the world but it's
a far cry from what a lot of people pile
on their plate and here's another oddity
the label of the spaghetti sauce says
that a serving of sauce is half a cup
so now my one FDA sanctioned portion of
spaghetti is swimming in sauce it kind
of makes you wonder if the pasta guy and
the sauce guy were talking to each other
the day they came up with the serving
sizes so how did we get here when
Congress told the phone and drug
administration to create standard
serving sizes in the early 1990s it said
they should match what Americans
typically ate at one sitting to find out
what that was
the FDA looked at surveys taken in the
1970s and 1980s where people were asked
about their eating habits the problem is
people often underestimate how much they
eat making the study suspect and
Americans have been eating more and more
which means many of the original
portions are now out of date the FDA
recognizes that there is a lot of
confusion out there about serving size
and nutrition information in general and
they're working to figure out ways to
make it easier for people to understand
until that happens the next time you go
to the supermarket you might want to
think about bringing a couple of things
along besides your shopping list
and your wallet how about a calculator
and a magnifying glass I'm Willy Newman
with the New York Times
